instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: Hello. I have problem with my LCD. Before repair screen showed up for a moment when lid was at 45 degrees. At 90 degrees there is no backlight. After few tries doesn't show at any degree. The flex cable from LCD backlight was broken (maybe make some short circuit). I've replaced whole LCD, and it still doesn't work. What should I check first to propertly diagnose and solve my problem? There is no image on external LCD. No sound, nothing.  My mainboard is 820-00875A (nyks 94v-0 nm19).

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Did you disable the battery, before start the screen changing?
Post F7000 and L7210 voltage, w/ and w/o LCD connected.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 89608, member: 682"]
Did you disable the battery, before start the screen changing?
[/QUOTE]
Did you mean disconnect battery from mainboard?

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: Good enough to disconnect data cable, J6951.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 89608, member: 682"]
Post F7000 and L7210 voltage, w/ and w/o LCD connected.
[/QUOTE]

w/0 LCD
F7000 13,04V
L7210 0V


w LCD
F7000 13,04V
L7210 0V

And I did disconnect the battery before start screen changing

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
Actually CPU core is not powered.
Check if you get voltage on other big coils.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Don't connect anything, apart of charger.

Check for knocked of components, or broken trace.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 89631, member: 682"]
Did you test the board alone on the desk?
Don't connect anything, apart of charger.

[/QUOTE]
Yes, I did.

[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 89631, member: 682"]
Check for knocked of components, or broken trace.

[/QUOTE]

There is no visible damaged components.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
You can't get video, nor other life sign, without CPU core (VCORE) present.
We don't know if you lost VCORE before replacing the screen, or just after changed it.

As VCCSA (L7370) is present, VCORE should come on too; being controlled by same U7100.
If not, you may have problems with PCH/CPU, BIOS, or some broken (ripped off) component, or trace.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: What else should I check to confirm what exactly is damaged?  Is there any way to solve this problem?

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
This is not an exact science.
If machine was working before you start changing the screen assembly, then very likely the damage has been done in the process.

Do not quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.
Maintain forum aesthetic, please.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: Ok. Even if I maked a mistake (but I don’t think so beacause I’m extra carefull in precise jobs) I think with your help I can find soliution. MacBooks are out of my knowledge but I can easly check mainboard piece by piece to figure it out.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
Post voltage for L7370, L7730, L7900/30/60, L8030/60.
Also check output voltages from page 64.

Just in case, check again L7210/20.

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
"U8200
Vout1 - PP1V8_S0 - 1,79V
[U][B]Vout1 - PP1V8_S3 - 9,21V[/B][/U]"
Are you sure about this?

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
Sorry it was P1V8S3SW_CT1.

PP1V8_S3 - 1,78V

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: What is the exact ohm resistance to ground at L7210?

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: resistance to ground at L7210 - 8.2 Ohm

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message:
If no broken component, or trace, then bad CPU.
Just in case, try known good BIOS...

threads.title: Macbook Pro A1708 820-00875A no image
threads.message: Is it possible to any element behind coils L7210 and L7220 is damaged and coil doesn't work because of this?
